Short version: 88%Like the first game, Syberia II uses its slow pace and dreamlike atmosphere to immerse the player in its wonderful world of clockwork machinery and snowy landscapes. As an adventure game, it also turned up the puzzle difficulty, sometimes significantly.Long version:Syberia II is, from beginning to end, one large journey, continuing straight from the ending scene of the previous game. Once again, we participate in a long trip of the returning protagonist, Kate Walker and the mysterious heir she chased all the way through the first game, Hans Voralberg.Syberia II is a sentimental tale, where the theme of the first game has matured into such questions as how long would someone go to fulfil their old dreams before their days run out, and how one can re-evaluate their purpose in life when they find a cause worthy enough to leave everything behind.As with most stories full of allegories, it is very slow and very dreamlike. The scenery reflects how our protagonists gradually leave the edge of civilisation as the last post of humanity, a small post-Soviet barter town fades into the distance of the vast Russian tundra, where the end of the tracks may hold the answer in their search of the last resting place of the remaining mammoths, the mythical island called Syberia.The game uses another tool to let the players immerse themselves in its world and atmosphere besides the slow pacing: the puzzles. They don’t use the warped point ‘n’ click logic that ruined many great games, but many of them rely on trial and error or constantly travelling from one end of a large gameplay area to another. The last third of the plot is especially notorious, where the difficulty quickly rises to almost legendary levels.But all that hardship will be worth it. Worth it for one of the most bittersweet, wonderful endings we can witness in an adventure game.

												I beat Syberia a year or two ago and while I really enjoyed it and knew that the journey continued in Syberia II, other games and life called me away. When I learned that Syberia 3 was in the works, a fire got lit underneath me and I finally played and finished Syberia 2 in preparation. I am so glad that I didn't play Syberia 2 until 3 was announced because I think I would have some seriously unanswered questions, but lets start from the beginning.Syberia II starts immediately after Syberia ends, so it is not so much a sequel as it is a continuation of the story. Now if you think that a game that has the story of a New York lawyer named Kate Walker going to Eastern Europe to wrap up a business deal and ends up instead helping an old man who is a genius with building automatons (NOT robots) go to the supposedly fictional island of Syberia where mammoths still live is boring, then move along. If however you think that that plot has possiblities you have to play it. I dare say it will be unlike any game you play. I know it stands out for me. Where to even begin? I love the world that Benoit Sokal has created. Even though it is mostly snow, and blizzards and vey remote locations on the fringe of civilization, it is gorgeous. The cut scenes are exciting, beautiful, and add to the overall mystic feel of the game. The soundtrack is a wonderful blend of regular orchestral music or a tribal feel, depending on where you are in the game. I love the characters. Seriously, if I were to pick a favorite heroine, it would be a tie between Commander Shephard and Kate Walker. I think Kate is that amazing. She doesn't save the world, but she questions the importance of having the ideal job in an ideal place. In her case it's a promising career in New York City. She learns how important it is to follow your dreams, and help others realize theirs, despite how crazy or off the beaten path they are. It's a real life lesson, and I think that is what makes her so special. The cast of characters that surround her are also memorable. I love Oscar. He may come off as annoying to some but personally I would love to go on a train adventure with him. The story really focuses on Hans, whom Kate is helping reach Syberia. It is his dream that is the focus and what drives Kate. The dynamic between these three makes this game special, and at times heartbreaking.Of course, you can't have an adventure game without the puzzles. The key is to talk to everyone about everything you can. This will give you clues about where to go. Each area feels like a kind of level, so there are only so much backtracking. The puzzles are everywhere from pretty easy, to definitely having to think. It will just depend of your experience with adventure games. Now I must address one thing - the ending. They got it right, mostly. Once the journey is over, there is definitely a loose string - Well, what now Kate Walker? Luckily, we will be getting the answer in Syberia 3, and I can't wait to see what new adventure she finds herself in.

												Excellent storyline defines this game's playability. Although the theme of the story doesn't seem special at all, the developer must be complimented for building a haunting gameplay upon it. Elements of longing, mysticism, fantasy, and mystery are well-blended, and will make you want to play further and further. Dialogues are well-written and entertaining. Visuals are dated and nothing special. While playing it on a 24" 1080p monitor wasn't a great experience – the blurry edges around all objects were quite visible – my enjoyment of the game wasn't impeded in any sense. Puzzles are quite straight-forward, and don't require any critical thinking skills; just be alert to your surroundings at all times, and pay special attention to all objects that your character can interact with, for be assured, such objects will have some use in the game.The only irritant – a big one – in the game is its tedious gameplay. Your character will need to walk around a lot in order to solve puzzles and find things and NPCs. All that could've easily been bypassed by making the character appear at the location of interest with a single click. But no! The sadistic game designers make you watch as the character meanders her way to the desired location, which will make you terribly impatient and peeved, and you might even turn-off the game in anger...only to return a few hours later :).SCORE: 7/10 (3 points deducted for tedious gameplay, average visuals, and unintelligent game design)PS: To play the complete story, you will need to play this game after Syberia, the first episode that sells as a separate game. However,  if, for some reason, you decide to play this game only, you will be briefed about what happened in the first episode via an option in the main menu. My recommendation is that you play both parts in order. This is a really good, no non-sense game, and its story will stay with you forever.

Syberia 2 reviewThe Good: The visuals and music are absolutely wonderful; there is a better variety in puzzles which makes the game more challenging.The Bad: There is slightly less character development than before; many of the cutscenes have very hammy dialogue ala the preview for the game.The original Syberia was an excellent game that came at a time when great adventures were scarce at best. It told a rich and enthralling story that left fans wanting more. In the two years since the original’s release, the adventure community has been through many disappointments, leaving Kate Walker again the task of breathing a little life back into the genre. There are a few slip-ups on the way, but thankfully Syberia II withstands those enough to succeed at its task.When we last saw our intrepid heroine, Kate Walker, she was jumping onto a train, essentially leaving her former life as a corporate yuppie lawyer behind to accompany the eccentric dreamer Hans Voralberg on his quest to find the land of Syberia. Syberia II picks up exactly where the first game left off, and in reality, this game should be looked at as more of a direct continuation of the first game, rather than a sequel that stands on its own. While there is a video recap of Syberia to assist new players, I don’t think that people who haven’t played the first game will care very much about the objective at hand. Therefore, I strongly recommend that if you have not played through the original Syberia yet, you should do so before taking on the sequel.As the game begins, your train makes a stop in Romansburg -- the last bastion of civilization before the endless tundra. After the opening cutscene, you gain control of Kate, and you will quickly realize that the interface is exactly as before: very simple and streamlined. Everything is completely point & click, with hotspots indicating when an item can be picked up or manipulated. By right-clicking you can access the inventory screen to either use or view items. It is so simple that anyone could start this game and ease right into the gameplay without having to consult a manual. There really are no interface differences between this and the first game to speak of, which I see as a good thing; the original interface worked just fine and by keeping it the same it makes the two halves feel like a single larger whole.The main complaint with Syberia was the short playing time and lack of challenging puzzles. It is obvious that the game developers took this criticism to heart, because the largest area of improvement in the game over its predecessor is indeed the puzzle design. The most impressive aspect of the game, to me, was the real effort to put a variety of puzzles into the game -- not just inventory-based puzzles as was the case before, but puzzles that run the gamut from the relatively simple inventory-based puzzles to more difficult logic-based ones -- you may even want to anticipate getting stuck for a while!(Something I never would have dreamed to happen in Syberia.) The addition of more varied puzzles that range in difficulty has helped lengthen the playing time to almost double that of the original game, giving the player much more bang for their buck.What the game gains in puzzle design though, it loses somewhat in character development. Kate’s motivations are very murky. In the first game, much of her personality and character arc is explained through her interactions with other in-game characters and her conversations on her cell phone. But as Kate wanders further and further away from civilization, meaningful character interactions become less and less common. In response to general criticism, the use of the cell phone has been marginalized in the sequel; although I am in the minority, I never minded the use of the cell phone as a storytelling device in Syberia. In a journey where your character is by herself most of the time, the presence of the cell phone is often the only thing to give the player insight into Kate’s emotions and thought processes. By all but removing that device, the game suffers from lack of character exposition. The player is left to extrapolate possible motivations for Kate based on assumptions, not by material that is present in the game.Also less prevalent in this game are the symbolisms that in part, made the first installment so interesting. The themes of life and death, spirituality vs. machinery, abandonment, loss, and faith are all still present, but they aren’t as tantalizingly de-constructible as before. What are very tantalizing, however, are the graphics. Once again, the Microids art department has outdone themselves. Everything is even more gorgeous this time around than the original, if that's possible. All of the cutscenes, the backgrounds, and the characters look beautiful and are all improved on in some way over the first game. The characters have better expressions, the backgrounds are more detailed, and the cutscenes are even more cinematic. You can tell that they put painstaking detail into everything seen on screen. There are also nice little realistic touches to each frame: birds can be seen flying, wind rustling in the trees, rushing water, animals scurrying across the snow and other things that may be unnecessary to the actual gameplay, but add indubitably to the atmosphere.Equally as wonderful is the sound. Each locale of the game features a musical theme that is well-suited to the mood of that place. The score is very well done and my only complaint would be that I want to hear more of it; it really is beautiful. The voice acting is also much more solid all around than it was in the first game, and the dialogue remains strong throughout, with one small exception: it tends to get a bit heavy-handed and cheesy during the cutscenes -– very reminiscent of the dialogue in the trailer that was released for the game.For many people, enjoying this game to the fullest will hinge on how much of a tradeoff they are willing to make between the story and the puzzles. Many of the original’s most vocal supporters loved it because of the storyline while many of its detractors criticized it for the lack of challenge. The developers took note of this and made a concerted effort to put in a greater variety of puzzles, but in doing so, the story -- in some respects -- falls by the wayside just a bit. However, the quality of the game as a whole is so outstanding that you will be willing to accept what is now a great story with improved puzzles, instead of what was a superb story with lackluster puzzles. Everyone should be able to find something -- most likely many things -- to admire about this game and I recommend it highly to everyone.

												Following its namesake, Syberia II features the American lawyer Kate Walker on her voyage alongside Hans Voralberg, an stunded genius and Oscar, their automaton train operator. Like its predecessor, the game is set in a post-Soviet backdrop of unspecified geography and features various locations ranging from a Russian mining town, a Monastery, and Subarctic forests, to Youkol settlements and even a dream-trance state of Valadilène (the town from the first game) through all of  which the player guides Walker throguh many difficulties of their journey. The plot, straightforward as it appears, features many details regarding Hans' obsessions, as well as Kate's former life, flesh out the storyline. There is an underlining theme of the Hans' quest comes across as one of almost prophetic proportions, which lends the game an odd mixture of magical realism tinged by the Art Nouveau-themes steampunk of many locations. The user interface is slightly cluncky and direction arrows may get slightly confusing at times. The same applies for the interface on puzzles: the game features only one icon for interaction (a magnifying lens) regardless of the nature or the direction of the said interaction. While this doesn't prevent puzzles from being solved (as they're not impossibly difficult anyway), it does nonetheless lack intutivity. Overall, Syberia II provides a fitting conclusion to Benoît Sokal's great duology (soon to be a trilogy, apparently). Its simple combination of a beautiful plot with elegant artwork makes Syberia II a necessary addition to adventure game collections even after more than a decade of its release.

												A solid, but often frustrating, end to the Syberia saga. The two Syberia games form a coherent, long-winded, beautiful journey, and they should be played together. This game brings the Voralberg storyline to a pretty satisfying, if a little underwhelming, conclusion. I really grew fond of these characters, environments and Benoit Sokal's style of epic storytelling, and I was saddened to see it end. These games have some of the most memorable moments in adventure gaming history, even if the world feels a bit sterile.The animation and the graphics are slightly improved over the first game. The gameplay is pretty much identical, however. My biggest gripes remain with the UI and the puzzles: 1) Finding "hot spots" is often like trying to find a needle in a haystack. Oftentimes you get stuck because you missed a doorway or a box of crates in some remote corner. Ugh. I really recommend keeping an FAQ at hand... 2) Especially because the puzzles can be really opaque and strange. Some of the puzzles are very logical and satisfaying. On the upside, the game is not trying to hold your hand. Everything is abstract and solvable. But unfortunately, on the downside, some of the solutions require a bit of psychotic tinkering. (As far as a good FAQ is concerned, I highly recommend the spoiler-free (!) UHS hint system: http://www.uhs-hints.com/uhsweb/hints/syberia2/1.php)Those who have invested time into the first game should definitely see the story to its conclusion. If the disappointing aspects of the gameplay - frustrating UI and obtuse puzzles - had been mitigated, this would have been a masterpiece.Overall: 7/10

content:
Posted: February 17
												     I am a total sucker for adventure games. My love affair with them started way back with Colassal cave, Scott Adams Adventures, and the famous Infocom games. Back then things were text based. Wishbringer, Hitchhiker's Guide to the galaxy, Enchanter, Suspended, Planetfall, Bureaucracy, The Lurking HOrror, and the everpopular ZORK were among my favorites. Adventure games have one game play premise. The Barter System (and right now the This for That Schoolhouse Rock song is playing in my head).  But that is the essence of the system. I have this, I give this person THAT and get another thing in return or they do something for me. Thus I progress in the story.      Now the purpose really is to tell a fun and interesting story while loading up with these puzzle exchanges. Graphics adventures of the sort were inevitable. THe best known were the Sierra company's titles like the King's QUest series, thus the POINT AND CLICK adventure was born. Thus a problem. Instead of getting a description of a room and things you can pick up, you are given a picture and have to see that these blocky pictures are actually objects as well as that there are exits...and sometimes not. Sure you can hover over an area to see if you can interact, but therein lies the problem. You HAVE to make things logical enough so that people will not only be able to tell where to go and that there might be something you can pick up.      Syberia 2 suffers bigtime from both obstacles. It is a sequel to a previous Syberia game, but that doesn't really matter. YOu can pick up easily that the lead character Kate has been away from work for awhile...and never wants to return. She instead sets off on another journey with an elderly friend to find Syberia, a place of myth and legend. It's an intriguing beginning that basically leads nowhere fast. Like King's Quest V, it suffers from lots of illogic in tasks you must do. Give a alligator to this character to get a key? No that's an exaggeration but there are some of the puzzles like that. THere is a lot of bait and switch in it. Oh I need a small key to get through this door. Rats. It doesn't work I think. Am I doing this right? I need a coin for this contraption. I have many coins. They don't seem to work. I have no idea what to do now.      This uncertainty is there because of the gameplay engine. When you hover it is a bit ambivvalent in what's happening. It uses a weird symbol to indicate that you CAN'T do something that is small and unclear and most importantly unlabeled and uninstructed. There is NO instruction whatsoever in fact. So you will waste a lot of time, say....trying a key in a door and wondering what you are doing wrong, not totally realizing that....it's just the wrong key....go find another one. It doesn't tell you it is wrong in ways that are obvious. Other games have big eyeball icons for looking, speech ballon for talking, hand for grabbing. Can't really say I can identify what the cursor is doing at any particular time except that it changes. Another gameplay issue is objects. You can use objects in your inventory to interact with objects in a given location. That isn't really obvious either. Mixed with the obtuse icons and cursors it takes a bit to figure it out when a simple 1 minute training area would have taken care of this.     It also definitely lacks logic in that it won't let you say and do things that seem obvious. Example. You talk to someone. They have a broken thing. You have a long conversation about your goal, your traveling companion, his ability to invent and fix things and that the two character even KNOW each other. THen in the end nothing becomes of it. It is obvious that you should go back to your friend and talk to him to tell him to go fix the thing right? But when you do it doesn't give you that option. Why not? I think the characters stand around asking themselves that.     The characters are indeed very good characters, some a bit natural, some cartoony. The lead character especially is appealing. However most of the characters don't want to help you with anything. Then out of nowhere they do. Then instead of actually saying logical things that flow, they clam up simply waiting around...bored in their existance. They almost look like they are frustrated about having nothing interesting to say. Talking with someone is easy. Just click on them and it gives you a series of topics to discuss. But that soon becomes a complete grind. They recycle information SO MUCH within each topic. Nothing goes in sequential order. You can get 5 layers deep in ONE topic conversation only to be told the exact same thing 2 layers down in another. And those conversations seem to go on forever without really getting to the point.      I do like the characters in general. The stories of each person are fine and make you want to know them more. The lead character is appealing enough to easily get most people on her side. But....this game and story is a bit of a depressing downer right from the getgo. I love the beginning of how her bosses are worried about her and that she hasn't come back to the office. "She's gone." says one. Meaning...wanderlust has totally consumed her. She's a different person now and will never return. Kate does indeed to be fulfilling that role...trying to help her dying old inventor friend find the mythical Syberia. So good strong beginning instantly sent on a downward depressing spiral dealing with an elderly friend whose mind is not all there and whose health slowly declines...in fact there are a series of interactions and puzzles dealing specifically with that. I don't want to watch a man dying and have to go through a lot of things just to get him treated just to be told he's going to die. On the upside this is a world like MYST, like Likehouse. Full of robots and contrption. Granted it has this supercharged locatamotive run by a robot and still has to use coal. What's with that? It then goes through a town whose economy is nonexistent because it has no travelers or money coming in on the last stop to nowhere. No wonder all the characters just stand around fidgety waiting for something to happen (which never does)     Overall there is no brightness at all to this game. Not in puzzles, not in interaction, not in story, not in logic. THere are some things that you just happen upon and they work. THere are others you didn't even realize and never would have guessed. THen there is the problem of having to constantly go from one of a towen to the other to your train back again, etc. It's a grind. Not fun at all. Especially when location logic too seems to suffer. LEt's see if I go under the train track I should be here then back this way I'm at the stairs. No wait I'm now at an engine. BUt that should be over by the house. Location placement is a bit off and not logical either making that running grind worse. Putting things as far apart as possible just to lengthen gameplay and then confuse you in how to get there....is a very very bad idea.    At end, the only great thing to say about this is that the characters are well formed, the scenerey gorgeous, the voice acting is great, especially Kate and the pearshaped Russian guy that sounds like Boris Badenov from Bullwinkle.

												I'm rewriting this review even though no one cares because I feel so strongly about my non-recommendation that it deserves a stronger defense than I'd given in the prior rant.I own Syberia II because I got the bundle for cheap. If I'd bought them individually, I wouldn't have bothered with part 2, as part 1 put me to sleep. Even after I gave up and watched a Let's Play instead, THAT put me to sleep. To be fair, 2 is a little less narcolepsy-inducing, but not enough for me to keep going beyond ALMOST getting out of the first area.It's rather discouraging, because the reviews are overwhelmingly positive otherwise. Why do so many other people enjoy what feels like a very pretty but dull exploration game? Because that's what it feels like--the "puzzles" are a bit obtuse (having spent far too long trying to figure out the basic controls during part 1), and much of the solutions are just find SOMETHING to interact with and try everything. It's not even enjoyable watching Kate Walker... walk... and walk... and walk... and walk BACK... etc. I can think of so many games that have a world that FEELS larger in fewer screens, just because the amount of interactive content per "room" is so much higher, and the attention to details that convey character in and of themselves. Syberia overall has a lot of empty content for really no reason other than I guess the art department planned out a map and the programmers worked around that. At least in part 2 there are fewer doors for Kate to declare she won't even bother trying to open.Furthermore, I realized that what I don't like about this style of point-and-click game is the "distant" feel of the characters. Every dialogue is from at least twenty feet away, perspective-wise, so it's more like eavesdropping than actual interaction. There are no close-ups (other than the shadowy cutscenes in part 2), so I get no feel for the characters' emotions except through the (kinda bad) translated voice-acting, because they're as stiffly animated as puppets. The closest it got to providing any depth or emotion was how part 1 kept interrupting what little gameplay there was with random phone calls that only served to show how much nobody really respected Kate, while part 2 took a different tack and put in sorely-needed cinematics (that seemed to inflate Kate's importance far above and beyond her original "buy a toy factory" job... but then I fell asleep through half the story to fully appreciate the drama).It's not like 3D can't accommodate the kind of character animation that 2D can provide easily--just look at any Telltale Games game (Sam & Max, The Wolf Among Us) or even a game like Ankh or the Gabriel Knight 20th Anniversary remake... though the GK remake admittedly feels as clunky as Syberia, the interview sections and cutscenes still draw the player out of "watch from a distance like a creepy stalker" mode enough to convey a real sense of who the characters are.Yes, I get that they were going for this realistic world to explore, and they've done a good job of that. Once I've seen a room once, though, it gets boring seeing it about fifty more times in trying to progress the story.tl;dr: Just watch a walkthrough on Youtube, it's a lot less clicking.

content:
Posted: January 13
												Couple Warnings:1) This review covers both Syberia games.2) While I'm saying I don't recommend it, I'm not saying it's a bad game. Hear me out, here. Not too long ago they had the "Syberia Bundle" on sale, so I thought I'd buy it with nothing to lose. It couldn't be that bad, if there's another sequel on the way, right? Again, as an adventure game, it's not bad. In fact, I think it did pretty good at setting up some challenging puzzles. But it's also nothing special. In a game like this, solving a puzzle is supposed to mean advancing the plot, but this game has barely enough plot to write a single novella, even if you use 100% of content from both Syberia games. Here's a quick TL;DR: 1) The plot is weak and nonsensical.2) World building and character development were thrown out the window altogether. You just have to take everyone's word for it that "Kate's Changed," because I can't tell a difference.3) The game features some glaring samples of bad level design, forcing the player to deal with issues that game devs had known were bad ideas for at least a decade before. ((((SPOILER)))) Plot of the first game can be summed up as "Young Lawyer Kate Walker goes to France to finalize paperwork on an automaton factory's takeover after the owner dies. However, the owner reveals in her will that her brother was still alive, and therefore she wants all her assets sent to him. All things considered, this should have still been the end of Kate's job, but her boss tells her not to come home until she gets that paperwork signed, so she travels to Russia hoping that just sort of maybe this brother will be there. On her way, we learn that her boss is an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and that her boyfriend is cheating on her with her best friend. All things considered, it's somewhat understandable that she chooses to run away with this brother, Hans, once she finally meets him." Sure, there's a train whose engineer is a robot who is your companion, but he refuses to lift a finger to assist in any way beyond "drive the train." Second game, Kate's traveling with Oscar the robot train driver and Hans the mammoth-obsessed idiot whose only redeeming feature is his ability to make Automatons. Hans gets sick and nearly dies, but he gets better after killing Oscar and turning his body into a brace. In the end, you make it to the magical island of Syberia, where wooly mammoths are still alive. ((((END SPOILER))))Considering what I know about the story so far, Syberia III is most likely going to just be "Kate goes back to civilization after completing her journey" and that's all we're going to get. And the worst part is, Kate's motivation is never clear. If these games made anything clear about her, it's that she isn't an idiot by any stretch of the imagination. Plus she was a lawyer. She knew her rights. She knew that her boss couldn't exactly fire her just because he didn't know all the facts before sending her into the field and it turns out the situation was more complicated than they expected. If she loved her job so much that she was willing to travel from France to Russia just to get one document signed, she would have known that travelling from France to Russia alone with no help was beyond her job description. Why the hell did she decide to throw away her relationships just to make her ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ boss happy?My other major complaint about the game is that there is next to no world building or character development, although I guess I already talked about poor character development. One of the main staples of point and click adventure games is that you can click on things to learn about them, or at least what the character knows about it. This helps you understand your environment and your character, but it's something that was sorely lacking from this game. Even some of those stupid Putt Putt and Freddie Fish games from the late 90's/early 2000's for kids 6 and under (which I played when I was 6 and under) did a better job of this, and they did it for an audience with a much shorter attention span. This game was for the 16-20 audience, and failed to deliver on one of the simplest questions anyone could ask of a story: "Why should I care?" Due to the fact you're surrounded by  strange devices, the sci-fi loving part of me cared from the first cutscene, but I could never rationalize caring beyond that. Lastly, although I've said many times that the game aspect was good, this game is the poster child for bad level design. In Syberia I, you are forced to run from one area to another multiple times, and half the areas in between bear no relevance to solving any puzzles or continuing the story. In Syberia II, they don't fix it. In fact, the only thing that got an update as far as I could tell was the layout of the train interior. That made no sense to update, though, since there would have been no time or reason for our characters to renovate it. I mean, Syberia II picks up one stop after Syberia I as far as I can tell. But that's the biggest gripe I think you can throw at any game series: This was a problem in the first game. You didn't fix it. Last thing. You know how the bullet points here on Steam say that the game has "Rich and intriguing new characters with new, realistically detailed 3D environments?" ignoring the game's age, I can't tell a difference between the graphics from the first game and the  second game. Also, the new characters? One's a dog, the other's a thief who follows you. I will say, though, that the dog is a good boy. I regret to say that once Syberia III costs 12.99 or less, I'll probably cave and buy it as well, but I can't see it being anything other than a quick cash grab.

												Played: Feb 2014PROS:+ More cinematics+ Voice acting better than episode I+ Does not have the graphics problem episode I had with switching to windowed mode in-gameCONS:- Story STILL does not go anywhere- Voice acting (English) still a bit sillyREVIEW: Let’s be honest: if I hadn’t purchased Syberia II along with Syberia I as a super-cheap combo pack, I wouldn’t have bothered at all. Everything that is “good” about Syberia II is only relatively good when compared with the terrible Syberia I; there is nothing superlative about any facet of this game.A good thing about this game is that it has more cinematics than its predecessor. A game that sells itself on story should have many movies, and there are some here. For a game released in 2004 the visuals are not bad, but they haven’t aged well at all and alone they shouldn’t induce you to buy this game. Furthermore, the voice acting won’t make you wince as often; as when intonation is way of or a word is mispronounced, but you will definitely notice strange moments in the dialogue.The main draw of this game is supposed to be the “amazing story” but here is the problem: it never develops beyond the premise that your protagonist wants to help an old guy reach Syberia (and still features the intelligence-insulting idea that he couldn't have gotten there when he built the rails the first time).In general, stories depend on the quality of conflict for their weight, and the weak opposition and half-sketched puzzles (either extremely easy or nonsensical due to total lack of clues) simply don’t contribute any to a satisfying conclusion. It’s more like you progress through a series of trivial events and the game stops. Even in its most pretentious moments trying to induce pathos, the characters never manage to be any more impactful than a mildly annoying fly at the dinner table.So what should induce you to buy this game? I can only imagine it must be the inflated ratings it seems to be getting elsewhere (why I tried when both games together were $3). Don’t bother unless you have time to waste and the patience of Job for flimsy characters (slightly less) annoyingly voiced.SPOILER PLOT COMPLAINT: One more thing I could leave off here-I couldn't believe it but the developers actually show you going so far north that you see Antarctic Emperor Penguins. Come on, were they complete idiots, or did they just think I'm one?REBUTTAL TO COMMENTS:On the contrary, the first game sets up a (boring) storyline which the second fails to resolve satisfactorily. I am seriously surprised you are defending the storyline; clearly I am not the one who hasn't put much thought into what is going on. Problems with the second story are significant and in actuality are catastrophic, ruining what little immersion you got in the first game.Premise of the First Game: A lawyer tries to find an idiot savant because it is buisness. She has a domineering mother and a needy boyfriend that she becomes increasingly distant from. She finds said idiot and decides to escort him (reasons are ambiguous but could possibly be construed as the "adventure and unknown" crap espoused). Game ends.Premise of Second Game: Having made the decision to escort the idiot savant to a location he has already built a train to, said person (no longer identified as a lawyer) solves breakdowns in said idiot's equipment (in spite of the fact that he is the "genius" that built it and presumably understands how to fix it)Protagonist overcomes resistance by enemies who have no clear reasons to oppose you.Protagonist makes "a tough ethical decision" to eliminate one of the most annoying side characters ever invented in order to help the idiot savant keep goingProtagonist gets idiot savant to final destination where he rides off into the sunset.Adventure over More Criticisms of Second Game: The game tries to give you catharsis by helping a fool achieve his life's dream, but it fails because he isn't credible as a character and neither is the protagonist, who is no longer motivated by escape (her motivation in part 2 is actually never further explained than "gee, I want to help this stranger out"). Enemies are less than two dimensional because they have zero motivation to oppose you, so they simply aren't believable. You deal with offensively stupid indigenous peoples and animals that literally could not live further from your proposed location. You seriously think those are the makings of a great game? This story was clearly written by the same 12-year-olds defending it below.

												Excellent storyline, it keeps you wanting more so am looking forward to Syberia 3! (tbc release date 2015)Pros:-Detail-rich graphics leave you admiring every scene, and contain steam-punk elements, all set against eerie snowy landscapes that are Russian and Inuit-esque.-More fictional history about the Youkols added further depth and intrigue, in particular epitomised in my favourite scenes involving the dream sequence and spirit woman.-Captivating and imaginative storyline with many architecturally-beatiful places to explore, it was great to see some of the same characters again while meeting totally new ones.was very sad re Oscar!-Better gameplay; Kate's movements are less clunky and running from scene to scene is less cumbersome than the first-Music and ambiance were really effective, I found myself completely in the game's environment for the most part (aka the surprise bear attack!)-Puzzles were interesting, more challenging than the first but not impossible.-The Youki was adorable <3 A seal-puppy hybrid is always a positive in my book!Cons:-Dialogue needed some work, exchanges between characters lacked some individuality and fun.  -Kate's character can be a tad bland at times, could be injected with a bit more humour or attitude as I found myself saying things that another person may in a given situation e.g. Bourgoff brothers acted awfully so I assumed she'd be a little more receptive to that!-There wasn't as much urgency re plot as the first so didn't feel as much momentum.Regardless, I still loved this game, a high 9/10.
